segment.source: Configures XAML compilation to join partial classes between markup and code-behind.
segment.target: Configures XAML compilation to join partial classes between markup and code-behind.

segment.source: The code partial class is defined in a separate code file, and the markup partial class is created by code generation during XAML compilation.
segment.target: The code partial class is defined in a separate code file, and the markup partial class is created by code generation during XAML compilation.

segment.source: xClass attribute
segment.target: xClass attribute

segment.source: x:Class attribute
segment.target: x:Class attribute

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Configures XAML compilation to join partial classes between markup and code-behind.
segment.target: Configures XAML compilation to join partial classes between markup and code-behind.

segment.source: The code partial class is defined in a separate code file, and the markup partial class is created by code generation during XAML compilation.
segment.target: The code partial class is defined in a separate code file, and the markup partial class is created by code generation during XAML compilation.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage
segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.source: XAML values
segment.target: XAML values

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: namespace
segment.target: namespace

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: Specifies a namespace that contains the partial class identified by classname.
segment.target: Specifies a namespace that contains the partial class identified by classname.

segment.source: If namespace is specified, a dot (.) separates namespace and classname.
segment.target: If namespace is specified, a dot (.) separates namespace and classname.

segment.source: If namespace is omitted, classname is assumed to have no namespace.
segment.target: If namespace is omitted, classname is assumed to have no namespace.

segment.source: classname
segment.target: classname

segment.source: Required.
segment.target: Required.

segment.source: Specifies the name of the partial class that connects the loaded XAML and your code-behind for that XAML.
segment.target: Specifies the name of the partial class that connects the loaded XAML and your code-behind for that XAML.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: x:Class can be declared as an attribute for any element that is the root of a XAML file/object tree and is being compiled by build actions, or for the Application root in the application definition of a compiled application.
segment.target: x:Class can be declared as an attribute for any element that is the root of a XAML file/object tree and is being compiled by build actions, or for the Application root in the application definition of a compiled application.

segment.source: Declaring x:Class on any element other than a page root or application root, and under any circumstances for a XAML file that is not compiled with the Page build action, results in a compile-time error.
segment.target: Declaring x:Class on any element other than a page root or application root, and under any circumstances for a XAML file that is not compiled with the Page build action, results in a compile-time error.

segment.source: The class used as x:Class cannot be a nested class.
segment.target: The class used as x:Class cannot be a nested class.

segment.source: The value of the x:Class attribute must be a string that specifies the fully qualified name of a class.
segment.target: The value of the x:Class attribute must be a string that specifies the fully qualified name of a class.

segment.source: You can omit namespace information so long as that is how the code-behind is structured also (your class definition starts at the class level).
segment.target: You can omit namespace information so long as that is how the code-behind is structured also (your class definition starts at the class level).

segment.source: The code-behind file for a page or application definition must be within a code file that is included as part of the project.
segment.target: The code-behind file for a page or application definition must be within a code file that is included as part of the project.

segment.source: The code-behind class must be public.
segment.target: The code-behind class must be public.

segment.source: The code-behind class must be partial.
segment.target: The code-behind class must be partial.

segment.source: CLR language rules
segment.target: CLR language rules

segment.source: Although your code-behind file can be a C++ file, there are certain conventions that still follow the CLR language form, so that there is no difference in the XAML syntax.
segment.target: Although your code-behind file can be a C++ file, there are certain conventions that still follow the CLR language form, so that there is no difference in the XAML syntax.

segment.source: In particular, the separator between the namespace and classname components of any x:Class value is always a dot ("."), even though the separator between namespace and classname in the C++ code file associated with the XAML is "::".
segment.target: In particular, the separator between the namespace and classname components of any x:Class value is always a dot ("."), even though the separator between namespace and classname in the C++ code file associated with the XAML is "::".

segment.source: If you declare nested namespaces in C++, then the separator between the successive nested namespace strings should also be "." rather than "::" when you specify the namespace part of the x:Class value.
segment.target: If you declare nested namespaces in C++, then the separator between the successive nested namespace strings should also be "." rather than "::" when you specify the namespace part of the x:Class value.
